0.user_question: Pat is to select six cookies from a tray containing only chocolate chip, oatmeal, and peanut butter cookies. There are at least six of each of these three kinds of cookies on the tray. How many different assortments of six cookies can be selected? (Note that cookies of the same type are not distinguishable.)

ost_step.1: First, let's calculate the total number of ways Pat can choose 6 cookies out of 18 cookies (6 of each kind): ${18 \choose 6}={18!}/({6!(18-6)!})=19683$.
ost_step.2: However, since the cookies of the same type are indistinguishable, there are fewer distinct assortments. For example, selecting 3 chocolate chip, 2 oatmeal, and 1 peanut butter cookie is the same as selecting 3 chocolate chip, 1 oatmeal, and 2 peanut butter cookies.
ost_step.3: Each choice corresponds to exactly ${6!}/({3!\cdot 2!\cdot 1!})$ arrangements. So, the total number of distinct assortments is ${19683}/{120}=163$.
